title: Lisa May Ceramics Website
text:
Quarto-based portfolio site for handmade ceramics.



pieces/ - Individual piece pages (.qmd files)
images/ - All images (JPG preferred, 1000px long edge currently, moving to 1600px)
mugs.qmd, etc. - Category listing pages





Categories: available for purchase, work in progress, sculpture, mugs, crows, whales, sgraffito, etc.
work in progress items should have draft: true (don’t publish unfinished pieces)
For sale items include “Available for Purchase” and “Price: $X” at top of content (two trailing spaces after “Purchase” for line break)
Alt text uses fig-alt attribute (not bracket syntax) to avoid visible captions
Lightbox galleries use group="name" attribute for navigation between images
Piece page pattern: hero image at top, then layout-ncol=2 or layout-ncol=3 grid for additional views
For 4 total images: use layout-ncol=3 (1 hero + 3 in one row)
For 5+ images: use layout-ncol=2 (1 hero + 2x2 grid)
Reference/meme images: save locally, display side-by-side with layout-ncol=2, add credit line at bottom in italics
Mugs include: “Durable stoneware, dishwasher and microwave safe.” before Process notes
Cropped detail images for callouts go outside lightbox group (no group= attribute)
Links between piece pages use .html extension (e.g., [sketchy crows](sketchy_crows.html))





All images have copyright: “© Lisa May”
Artist/Creator: “Lisa May”
Copyright Notice: “© Lisa May - lisamayceramics.com”
GPS and device info stripped for privacy



exiftool -overwrite_original \
  '-GPS*=' \
  -Make= \
  -Model= \
  -Software= \
  -SerialNumber= \
  -LensInfo= \
  -LensModel= \
  -LensSerialNumber= \
  -Copyright="© Lisa May" \
  -Artist="Lisa May" \
  -Creator="Lisa May" \
  -CopyrightNotice="© Lisa May - lisamayceramics.com" \
  images/*.jpg images/*.png





Web research is authorized (viewing websites for pricing, technique info, etc.)




Lisa May - lisamayceramics.com

title: To-Do
text:
To-Do

Add alt text to all images
Make “work in progress” category automatically set as draft (don’t publish unfinished pieces)
Reorganize top menu:

“Available for purchase” first
Gallery second
Category pages (mugs, etc.) less prominent

Add section for new work not yet available (to show friends)

Expand artist statement
Add commissions language (inquiries welcome, selective about projects — cool ideas from good people)

title: Golden Green Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $50
Volume: 248 mL (8 oz)



















This is a smaller mug (8 oz / 248 mL), and it’s wierd, wonderful, and one-of-a-kind. This glaze is called Golden Green and I’m falling in love with the weird olive green/yellow.
This is based on drawings from my crows in my backyard, a sister to sketchy crows.

title: Crow Babies
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $45
Email may.lisa2@gmail.com to inquire.

This summer I watched a juvenile crow beg for food while she was standing on food. The begging went on for days. Man, oh man, it really made me empathize with the parents. And crows do it every year! This a set of four small plates is an ode to parental patience and how hard it is to raise kids. :) They’re little plates - perfect for dunking chicken nuggets in ketchup or holding your rings.

title: Holy Whale
text:
Available for Purchase
Price: $225
Male humpbacks sing for hours, spiraling slowly as their voices carry for miles. This sculpture holds that moment — peaceful, embodied, part of the great chorus.




































Hand sculpted in stoneware for lasting durability, indoors or out. Dimensions: 16” × 8” × 4” (41 × 20 × 10 cm). Two mounting holes allow for easy hanging with nails, screws, or wire.
Stoneware goes through two firings. Here it is after sculpting, before the first fire — and a glimpse of the hollowing process that makes large pieces possible.

title: Singing Whale
text: Sigh. I really loved this whale, but I screwed up the glazing. So we’ll just say that I learned a lot. Maybe someday I’ll try to reglaze and fire.

title: Mark Making Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $50
Volume: 410 mL (14 oz)
























This mug, she shines bright. Guaranteed good vibes with bright orange and turquoise. It gives me the feeling of a herd of animals moving across a plain or tropical fish in a coral reef. Collective life, moving together, vibrant color.
It’s a great mug for holding, the texture is very satisfying.
Durable stoneware, dishwasher and microwave safe.
Process notes
I woke up in the middle of the night to carve this. Each mark is hand carved. Small repetitive hand movements are so soothing. Then it was bisque fired and I added the turquoise, wiped it back so only the blue stayed in the marks, and added clear glaze.

title: Sketchy Crows Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $50 Volume: 182 mL (6 oz)
























She’s a small mug (6 oz/182 mL), for a Sunday morning when you’re close to the coffee pot or have a pot of tea brewing. Or maybe you’re just an elegant person who drinks in small volumes.
This crow from behind is my favorite. Mysterious. 
Then she turns and makes awkward eye contact. Whut? 
This is the least successful carving although the one I love the most from the reference sketch. I can’t get that head tilt right yet! 
This mug marks a turning point based on a fluid sketch, less like a plan with very clear clean outlines, less like a cartoon, less controlled. I like stuff that has a weird messy energy.
Carving clay feels amazing. Sometimes I crave it (not making that up). I loved the chaos of carving those horizontal stripes. Chaos gremlin release!
Durable stoneware, dishwasher and microwave safe.
Process notes
This is the reference sketch I made to work from. 
And here’s an example of the reference pictures I’m taking of MY CROWS lately because they trust me and come when I whistle and come very close to me. Squeeeeeeeeeeee.

title: Doors Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $50
Volume: 577 mL (20 oz)














This is a big, bold mug — 20 oz (577 mL) — for someone who wants to commit to their coffee.
The design is based on medieval cathedral doors. I’ve been thinking about doors lately as points of transition, especially house doors. The transition between what’s internal and private vs. external and public. How we navigate those choices. Doors to different futures, possible choices, other dimensions.
This piece marks a turning point for me: it’s where I started treating mugs as tiny canvases, sketching out a composition based on the space.

title: Pod of Whales
text:
These whale were in my mind for a long time.


I used to work in an office space with a super high ceiling, and I had this image of the ocean and the different biological niches. You know, the sunlight zone, the twilight zone… we were the bottom dwellers in this tall tall space and there could be different biological niches above us and we’d just be oblivious to it.




 


 



In real life, it can feel like your entire biological niche changes when you change your social circle. Like…changing your job or go through a breakup…like you live in the same town but never see all the people you used to see every day. Or you start a new hobby or make a new friend and that gives you a whole new social world. All of these lives are going on around us and it doesn’t take much to make the world feel totally different.










The feeling of the different whales relating to one another— they’re playing, they’re dancing, they’re in their bodies and joyful. Movement. A sense of movement and connectedness. What must it feel like to dive like that? To be that powerful of a swimmer?

title: Papaya
text: The color blending is just right on the back.

title: Buckwheat Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $40
Volume: 522 mL (18 oz)














Listen, don’t tell the rest of the mugs, but right out of the kiln this is one of the best mugs of its cohort.
It’s big, it’s strong, it’s a simple mug. It’s not an artist, it might not be interesting with crows or such, but it doesn’t need all that. It’s perfect as it is.
Also obsessed with this buckwheat glaze. On a test tile I was all “boring, when would I ever want that?”
But for this it’s just right. Look at how it breaks over the carving, it’s eeeeiiii so good.

title: Belly Dancer Whale
text: She’s a beautiful dancer, spinning on her belly.

title: Tea Cannister
text: The bottom is cool because I used a parmesan cheese jar as a form. :) Also this holds Trader Joe’s teabags just like a can of pringles.

title: Contact
text: Hi! To purchase a piece, send an email to may.lisa2@gmail.com.

title: Real Good Hammered Mug
text: It’s not even hammered. I mean…I hit it with a ball tool which I love doing with all my heart.

title: Hammered Mug the Second
text: Honestly, the first hammered mug was way better. I was experimenting with thinner slabs to make the mugs lighter, but I’ve learned that means they warp more easily.

title: Stars Cup
text: Gasp. This one gives me the feels. I should make more in this theme.

title: Mina and the Leaf
text: I’m real proud of this one. Gives just the Emily Dickenson staring into the sky vibes. Based off an actual photo - the leaf was (and is) that big.

title: Stars & Mountains Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $50
Volume: 413 mL (14 oz)














Inspired by looking at a picture of this stars cup, I made this! For these, I always need the mountains/land/horizon to be waaaayyy down on the mug, because I’m chasing that feeling of laying in a field as a kid in the plains of Montana, with the sky a bowl above me. BIG SKY.
This mug will do you right. She’s good to hold, she’s a good size (14 oz/413 mL), good vibes.
Durable stoneware, dishwasher and microwave safe.
Process Pic

title: About
text:
I have a PhD in Neuroscience from the University of Oregon and work as a Workflow Coach for Posit Software.
I tend to find the social lives of non-human animals interesting - thus crows and whales as subject matter.
